item.title: Fortnite iOS Return in UK "Uncertain" Thanks to CMA Decisions, Epic Says
item.content:encoded:
Epic Games has revealed that it doesn't know whether Fortnite will be returning to the iOS platform in the UK, following the release of two CMA (Competition & Markets Authority) roadmaps regarding Google and Apple's mobile platforms.

In a post on its website, Epic says that Fortnite's "return to iOS in the UK is now uncertain" thanks to the CMA's decisions, and that it "can't bring the Epic Games Store to iOS in the UK this year (if ever)".

For context, the CMA laid out roadmaps for market status investigations into Google and Apple respectively today, and in both cases, requiring the two companies to allow developers to point users to other app stores and payment methods falls under measures the authority "will consider from the first half of 2026".

Epic calls this a "missed opportunity to introduce competition into a currently-monopolized market". It's a decision that's contradictory to one recently made by the European Commission, which saw Apple slapped with a €500 million fine and forced to "inform customers, free of charge, of alternative offers outside the App Store".

According to Epic, Apple and Google must be "completely blocked from imposing fees and discriminating against apps using out-of-app payment" if "years of malicious compliance...and no genuine restoration of market competition" are to be avoided.

All of this is to say that if you've been hoping to play Fortnite on your iPhone or iPad in the UK, then it looks like you're going to have a long while to wait; the earliest you can likely expect to play the game on your device is 2026, but it could take even longer than that.

For years now, Epic has been embroiled in legal battles with both Apple and Google over allowing alternate payment systems and storefronts on the two companies' Android and iOS operating systems.

The fight began back in 2020, when Epic launched a sale that promised discounts if players used the Fortnite studio's proprietary payment system. Fortnite was removed from Android and iOS as a result, and Epic sued both companies, kicking off the ongoing legal struggle.

Of course, if you're not in the UK, your iOS Fortnite prospects might be a bit rosier; in May, the game was restored to the US App Store, and of course, Fortnite is also available on Android via the Epic Games Store. If you're in the UK, though, you'll just have to wait for more on this.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Gran Turismo 7 Update Brings Ridiculously Rare Car and More
item.content:encoded:
Sony and Polyphony Digital have announced a new Gran Turismo 7 update, and this one's giving you the chance to drive a ridiculously rare car, plus two other gorgeous vehicles.

As revealed in a news post on the official Gran Turismo website, update 1.61 will either land today or tomorrow depending on where you are. It's set to arrive tonight at 10pm Pacific, so that's 1am Eastern or 6am GMT tomorrow.

Just like previous Gran Turismo 7 updates, the game's latest patch will be bringing three cars for you to drive, but there's a special addition in update 1.61 in the form of the '05 NISMO R34 GT-R Z-tune. If you're a rare car aficionado, you'll probably know what that means.

The story behind this one is pretty special. You can see a full breakdown in this PlayStation Blog post, but essentially, only 19 Z-tunes were made, and they're all constructed from stripped-down used cars with high-spec part replacements.

As well as the Z-tune, you can also expect to drive the '22 Honda N-ONE RS, a kei passenger car with front-wheel drive and a 6-speed manual transmission. It's a light, breezy vehicle with plenty of modern accouterments to keep you happy.

Finally in this update, the '22 Nissan Qashqai Tekna 190 2wd e-Power is a hybrid machine that features a revolutionary (no pun intended) electric-generating engine. The aim was to improve on previous models' emissions, a goal Nissan clearly reckons it's achieved.

You can see these cars in action right here in the Gran Turismo 7 Update 1.61 trailer. It's not very long, but it does give a sense of what these beasts are like on the track.

Gran Turismo 7 Update 1.61 is due to land today at 10pm Pacific, or tomorrow at 1am Eastern/6am GMT. You can grab Gran Turismo 7 right now on PS5 and PS4.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Ubisoft to Reorganize Into "Creative Houses" as Q1 Financials Disappoint
item.content:encoded:
Ubisoft has revealed that it intends to undergo a major internal restructuring into new units called "Creative Houses", following disappointing first-quarter financial results for the company.

As part of its latest financial statement, Ubisoft says these "Creative Houses" will help to "enhance quality, focus, autonomy, and accountability" across the company. The new entity Ubisoft created earlier this year to shepherd its core IP will serve as the first Creative House, but we don't know what the others will be yet.

In terms of financials, Ubisoft reported a 3.9% drop in sales when compared to the previous year, as well as a 2.9% drop in net bookings. The studio blames "a lower-than-expected performance for Rainbow Six Siege", as well as "a partnership that is now expected to materialize in Q2".

Despite these underwhelming figures, Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot reveals that recent tentpole release Assassin's Creed Shadows now has "more than 5 million unique players". Presumably, that translates to sales as well, given that the game isn't available on subscription services.

This performance, Ubisoft says, is "in line with expectations", so while the game hasn't been disappointing, it also hasn't exceeded Ubisoft's predictions. The studio also looks forward to the release of Star Wars Outlaws on Switch 2, which it expects will help the game "reach a broader audience".

It hasn't been the best couple of years for Ubisoft. In May, the studio released its summary for the preceding fiscal year, which showed that both sales and profits were down compared to the previous year despite the release of Assassin's Creed Shadows.

Prior to that, in December last year, Ubisoft announced it would shut down the live-service shooter XDefiant and close two of its studios, with the French gaming outfit going on to close another location in January.

Aside from the aforementioned Switch 2 release of Star Wars Outlaws, it must be said that Ubisoft's release slate is looking a little barren for the next few months, so I wouldn't be surprised if the studio registers another drop in the second quarter. We'll have to wait and see what happens.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Splitgate 2 to Go Back to Beta as Layoffs Loom
item.content:encoded:
Splitgate 2 developer and publisher 1047 Games has announced that the portal-based first-person shooter will be going back into beta, and that several staff members will be losing their jobs as a result.

In a post on social media, 1047 acknowledges that Splitgate 2 "launched too early", and that in releasing the game, the studio "bit off more than [it] could chew", making "boneheaded mistakes" along the way.

As a result, Splitgate 2 will be "going back to beta", 1047 says, which means that "major parts" of the shooter will be rebuilt "to capture the spirit of what made Splitgate special".

While in its new beta period, Splitgate 2's progression will be reworked, more portals will be added to its maps, and monetization will be simplified, according to 1047 Games. Not only that, but the studio will be "refocusing on classic game modes" the community has "been asking for".

As part of "rebuilding the core experience" of Splitgate 2, which 1047 Games says is not a "quick fix", the studio says it'll be laying off employees to "shift [its] resources to focus" on the rework. 1047 Games doesn't state how many employees will be losing their jobs.

The studio does, however, say that it intends to "retain as many team members as possible", and that as a result of doing so, the servers for the original Splitgate will be shut down next month. As a reminder, updates for that game ended back in September 2022.

If you're an avid Splitgate player, however, you'll be pleased to know 1047 says it's "exploring the possibility of supporting offline or peer-to-peer matches", so while nothing has been decided yet, it's not necessarily over for Splitgate.

Despite dropping back into beta, Splitgate 2 isn't going away; it'll still be available to play, and Chapter 3 will be released as planned. However, it sounds like more big updates won't be released until Splitgate 2 is ready for release (again).

In the meantime, you can check out Splitgate 2 right now on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: New PS5 Software Beta Makes Multi-Device DualSense Switching Easier
item.content:encoded:
Sony has announced a new PS5 system software update beta, and if you like to use your DualSense controller across other devices besides your console, then you're in luck.

As revealed in a new PlayStation Blog post, the beta will start rolling out tomorrow. The main feature being introduced in this update is the ability to pair your DualSense with multiple devices, making it easier to switch between them whenever you like.

At the moment, if you want to switch from using your DualSense on your PS5 to using it on a PC, for instance, you need to pair the controller with the new machine every time you want to swap, but when the new update lands, that won't be the case anymore.

The new update will allow you to register your DualSense with up to four compatible devices at once, and all you need to do in order to switch from one device to another is press the PlayStation button and one of the face buttons.

Once you've assigned a device to one of the face buttons, switching to that device will show a different number of player indicator lights on your controller, corresponding to the device you have connected. It's that simple!

Of course, you can also continue to use your DualSense via wired USB connection if your device supports it as well, but it's nice to know that switching between wireless connections will get easier.

As well as the new DualSense switching feature, Sony has also revealed a new Power Saver feature as part of its Road to Zero environmental plan. It won't be live in this update, but when it does arrive, you'll be able to cut performance in certain PS5 games in order to reduce power consumption.

We don't yet know which games will support this feature, nor do we know when it'll land, but with many potentially demanding games on the horizon in terms of performance, it's probably better for Power Saver to land sooner rather than later.

In any case, the new PS5 system software beta begins rolling out in certain territories tomorrow. We don't know when the full release is coming yet, so stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
